quotation: Boni pastoris est tondere pecus non deglubere.
translation: It is the duty of a good shepherd to shear his sheep, not to flay them.
notes: A saying of Tiberius Caesar, in reference to excessive taxation.

quotation: Boni venatoris est plures feras capere non omnes.
translation: It is the business of a good sportsman to take much game, not all.
notes: From Notes to Horace, by Nannius.

quotation: Boni viri omnes aequitatem ipsam amant.
translation: All good men love justice for its own sake.

quotation: Bonis avibus.
translation: With good omens.

quotation: Bonis inter bonos quasi necessaria est benevolentia.
translation: Between good men there is a necessary interchange, as it were, of good feeling.

quotation: Bonis nocet quisquis pepercerit malis.
translation: He injures the good, who spares the wicked.
notes: Misplaced sympathy is an injury committed against society.

quotation: Bonis quod benefit haud perit.
translation: A kindness done to the good is never lost.
notes: Good deeds are never ill-bestowed.

quotation: Bono ingenio me esse ornatam, quam auro multo mavolo.
translation: I had much rather that I was adorned with a good disposition than with gold.

quotation: Bonum ego quam beatum me esse nimio dici mavolo.
translation: I would much rather be called good than fortunate.

quotation: Bonum est fugienda aspicere in alieno malo.
translation: It is well to see what to avoid in the misfortunes of others.

quotation: Bonum est, pauxillwm amare sane, insane non bonum est.
translation: It is good to love in a moderate degree; to love to distraction is not good.

quotation: Bonum magis carendo quam fruendo sentitur.
translation: A good is more valued when we are in want of it, than when we enjoy it.
notes: The value of good health is only truly estimated by the sick man.

quotation: Bonum summum quo tendimus omnes.
translation: That ultimate good at which we all aim.

quotation: Bonus animus in mala re dimidium est mali.
translation: Good courage in a bad case is half of the evil got over.

quotation: Bonus arator agricultione se oblectat, cultu saepe defatigatur, cultura ditescit.
translation: A good husbandman takes delight in agriculture; he is often wearied with his labours, but by culture he gets rich.

quotation: Bonus atque fidus Judex honestum praetulit utili.
translation: A good and faithful judge prefers the honest to the expedient.

quotation: Bonus dux bonum reddit militem.
translation: A good general makes good soldiers.

quotation: Bonus judex secundum asquum et bonum judicat, et aequitatem strictae legi praefert.
translation: A good judge gives judgment according to what is equitable and right, and prefers an equitable construction to the strict letter of the law.

quotation: Bos alienus subinde prospectat foras.
translation: The strange ox repeatedly looks to the door.
notes: Significant of that love of home which pervades the animated creation.

quotation: Bos fortius fatigatus figit pedem.
translation: The wearied ox treads the surest.

quotation: Bos in lingua.
translation: An ox on his tongue.
notes: Said of a man who had been bribed, as the Athenians had money stamped with the figure of an ox.

quotation: Breve tempus aetatis satis est longum ad bene honesteque vivendum.
translation: A short life is long enough for us to live well and honestly.

quotation: Brevi manu.
translation: With a short hand.
notes: Off-hand, in a summary manner.

quotation: Brevis esse laboro, Obscurus fio.
translation: While I endeavour to be brief, I become obscure.
notes: Said of authors who, aiming at conciseness, give their readers credit for knowing too much. The exclamation of Thomas Warton, on accidentally snuffing out a candle.

quotation: Brevis ipsa vita est, sed malis sit longior.
translation: Life itself is short, but it may last longer than your misfortunes.
notes: Somewhat similar to our proverb, "It is a long lane that has no turning."

quotation: Brevis voluptas mox doloris est parens.
translation: Short-lived pleasure is the parent of speedy sorrow.

quotation: Brutum fulmen.
translation: A harmless thunderbolt.
notes: Big words; the groans of the mountains when they were delivered of the mouse.

quotation: Cacoethes.
translation: A bad habit.
notes: This is a Greek word Latinized, which has been adopted in other languages.

quotation: Cacoethes carpendi.
translation: An itch for finding fault
notes: or "carping at."

quotation: Cacoethes scribendi.
translation: An itch for scribbling.

quotation: Cadit quaestio.
translation: There is an end on the question.
notes: The matter requires no further investigation. See Casus quaestionis.

quotation: Caeca invidia est, nec quidquam aliud scit quam detractare virtutes.
translation: Envy is blind, and knows not how to do aught but detract from the virtues of others.

quotation: Caeci sunt oculi, cum animus res alias agit.
translation: The eyes are blind, when the mind is intent upon somethinig else.

quotation: Caecus non judicat de colore.
translation: A blind man is no judge of colours.

quotation: Caesarem portas, et fortunas ejus.
translation: Thou carriest Caesar and his fortune.
notes: Said by Caesar to the pilot in the tempest.

quotation: Caetera desunt.
translation: The rest is wanting.

quotation: Caetera quis nescit?
translation: The rest who knows not?

quotation: Calamitas querula est et superba felicitas.
translation: Adversity is complaining, and prosperity proud.

quotation: Calamitosus est animus futuri anxius.
translation: The mind that is anxious about future events, is miserable.

quotation: Campos ubi Troja fuit.
translation: The fields where Troy once stood.

quotation: Callidos eos appello, quorum tanquam manus opere sic animus usu concalluit.
translation: I call those experienced, whose minds become strengthened just as the hands are hardened by labour.

quotation: Calumniare fortiter, aliquid adhaerebit.
translation: Slander stoutly; some of it will stick.

quotation: Calumniari si quis autem voluerit, Quod arbores loquantur, non tantum ferae; Fictis jocari nos meminerit fabulis.
translation: But if any one shall think fit to cavil, because not only wild beasts, but even trees speak, let him remember that we are disporting in the language of fable.
notes:
"'Tis clear that birds were always able 
To hold discourse, at least in fable." Cowper.

quotation: Camelus desiderans cornua etiam aures perdidit.
translation: The camel begging for horns lost its ears as well.
notes:
We should be thankful for the faculties with which Providence 
has endowed us, and not wish for those which are inconsistent with our condition.

quotation: Camelus saltat.
translation: The camel is dancing.
notes: Said of a person doing something quite repugnant to his ordinary habits.

quotation: Candida me capiet, capiet me flava puella.
translation: The blonde will charm me, the brunette will charm me too.

quotation: Candida pax homines, trux decet ira feras.
translation: Fair peace becomes human beings, savage fury wild beasts.

quotation: Candida, perpetuo reside, concordia, lecto, Jamque pari semper sit Venus aequa jugo: Diligat illa senem quondam; sed et ipsa marito, Tunc quoque cum fuerit, non videatur anus.
translation: Pair concord, ever attend their bed, and may Venus ever prove auspicious to the well-matched pair; may she at a future day love her old man; and may she, even when she is so, not appear to her husband to be aged.

quotation: Candidus in nauta turpis color: aequoris unda Debet et a radiis sideris esse niger.
translation: A fair complexion is unbecoming in a sailor; he ought to be swarthy, from the spray of the sea and the rays of the sun.

quotation: Candor dat viribus alas.
translation: Candour imparts wings to strength.

quotation: Canes socium in culina nullum amant.
translation: Dogs love no companion in the kitchen.
notes: See Figulus, &c, and Unus(?) domus, &c.

quotation: Canes timidi vehementius latrant quam mordent.
translation: With cowardly dogs, the bark is worse than the bite.

quotation: Canina facundia.
translation: Dog eloquence.
notes: Mentioned by Quintilian as that kind of eloquence which distinguished itself in snarling at others. See Littera canina.

quotation: Canis festinans caecos parit catulos.
translation: The bitch, in making too much naste, brings forth her whelps blind.
notes:
Said of persons who are in too great a hurry to put the 
finishing stroke to what they have undertaken.

quotation: Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator.
translation: The traveller with empty pockets, will sing in presence of the robber.
notes: He who has nothing to lose is in no fear of being robbed.

quotation: Cantantes licet usque (minus via laedet) eamus.
translation: Let us sing as we travel on, the journey will be all the less tedious.

quotation: Cantat, et ad nautas ebria verba jacit.
translation: He sings aloud and cracks his drunken jokes upon the sailors.

quotation: Cantat vinctus quoque compede fossor, Indocili numero cum grave mollit opus. Cantat et innitens limosae pronus arenae, Adverso tardam qui trahit amne ratem.
translation: The miner, chained with the fetter, sings as he lightens his heavy labours with his untaught numbers; and the man sings, who strives as he bends forward on the oozy sand, while he drags the slow barge against the tide.

quotation: Cantate Domino.
translation: O sing unto the Lord (a new song).
notes: Beginning of the 98th Psalm.

quotation: Cantilenam eandem canis.
translation: You are singing the same tune.
notes: Like our expression, " You are always harping on one string."

quotation: Capias.
translation: You may take
notes: the body of the defendant, under either a

quotation: Capias ad respondendum.
translation: You may take him to make answer.
notes: A writ issued to take the defendant and make him answer to the complaint, ‚Äî or a

quotation: Capias ad satisfaciendum.
translation: You may take him to satisfy.
notes:
A writ of execution on a judgment obtained, commanding the officer to imprison the defendant until 
satisfaction is made for the debt recovered against him.

quotation: Captantes capti sumus.
translation: We catchers are caught.
notes: The biter is bitten.

quotation: Capistrum maritale.
translation: The noose matrimonial.

quotation: Capita aut navem?
translation: Head or ship?
notes:
Or as we say, "Head or tail." "Cross or pile?" The copper coins of Rome had on one side the double head of Janus, on the other the 
figure of a ship.

quotation: Capitis nives.
translation: The snows of the head.
notes: White hair.

quotation: Captum te nidore suae putat ille culinae.
translation: He thinks he has caught you with the fumes of his kitchen.
notes: He thinks that you will submit to anything for a good dinner.

quotation: Caput artis est, decere quod facias.
translation: It is the perfection of good management, to let all that you do be becoming.
notes:
Every one should endeavour to act in a manner 
becoming to his age and position.

quotation: Caput mortuum.
translation: The dead head.
notes:
A term used in chemistry, meaning the residuum of a substance that has been acted on by heat. By punsters the term has been applied 
to a blockhead.

quotation: Caput mundi.
translation: The head of the world.
notes:
The designation of ancient Rome in the days of her splendour. It is still applied, by Roman Catholics, to modern Rome, as the 
see of the head of their religion.

quotation: Cara fuit, conjux, primeae mihi cura juventae Cognita; nunc ubi sit quaeritis? Urna tegit.
translation:
I once had a dear wife, known as the choice of my early 
youth. Do you ask where she is now ? The urn covers her.
notes: Lines full of pathos.

quotation: Carbone notare.
translation: To mark with charcoal.
notes: To place a black line against the name of a person was to signify disapproval.

quotation: Caret insidiis hominum, quia mitis, hirundo.
translation: The swallow is exempt from the snares of men, because it is gentle.

quotation: Caret periculo, qui etiam cum est tutus cavet.
translation: He is secure against danger who, even when in safety, is on his guard.
notes:
This caution must however be used, without be
ing over anxious about the future. See "Calamitosus est," &c.

quotation: Cari sunt parentes, cari liberi, propinqui, familiares; sed omnes omnium caritates patria una complexa est.
translation: Dear are our parents, dear our children, our relatives, our frieuds; but our country in itself embraces all of these affections.

quotation: Caritate benevolentiaque sublata, omnis est e vita sublata jucunditas.
translation: Charity nnd benevolence removed, all the delights of life are withdrawn.

quotation: Carmen triumphale.
translation: A song of triumph.

quotation: Carmina nil prosunt; nocuerunt carmina quondam.
translation: Verses are of no use; verses once did me harm.

quotation: Carmine fit vivax virtus; expersque sepulchri, Notitiam serae posteritatis habet.
translation: By verse is virtue made immortal; and, secure from death, it thereby obtains the notice of late ppsterity.

quotation: Carni vale.
translation: Adieu to flesh.
notes: Hence the Carnival of the Romish Church, the beginning of Lent.

quotation: Carpe diem quam minime credula postero.
translation: Seize upon to-day, trusting as little as possible in the morrow.
notes: The poet says this in conformity with the Epicurean maxim, "Eat, drink, and be merry, for to-morrow we die;" but it may admit of a more extended and more useful application, and teach us not to put off till to-morrow what may be done to-day.

quotation: Caseus est nequam quia concoquit omnia secum.
translation: Cheese is injurious, because it digests all things with itself.
notes: The saying is at the present day, that cheese digests all things but itself.

quotation: Caseus est sanus quem dat avara manus.
translation: Cheese, when given with a sparing hand, is wholesome.
notes: Aphorism of the School of Health at Salerno.

quotation: Cassis tutissima virtus.
translation: Virtue is the safest helmet.
notes: Motto of the Marquis of Cholmondeley.

quotation: Casta ad virum matrona parendo imperat.
translation: A virtuous wife, by obeying her husband, gains the command over him.

quotation: Castor gaudet equis, ovo prognatus eodem - Pugnis.
translation: Castor delights in horses, he that was born from the same egg, in boxing.
notes:
All men have their own peculiar 
tastes.

quotation: Casus belli
translation: A cause for war.

quotation: Casus in eventu est.
translation: The result is doubtful.

quotation: Casus omissus.
translation: A case omitted.
notes: A case for which provision was not made in the statute under consideration, either from neglect, or from the fact of its antecedent improbability.

quotation: Casus quaestionis.
translation: Loss of question.
notes: In Logic, this means the failure to maintain a position. This is most probably what is alluded to in a passage of Shakspeare, which has so puzzled his commentators, "As I subscribe not these nor any other, But in the loss of question." Measure for Measure, A. ii. s. 4.

quotation: Casus quem saepe transit, aliquando invenit.
translation: He whom misfortune has often passed by, is by it at last assailed.
notes:
Good fortune, however long continued, is no 
pledge of future security. "The pitcher that goes oft to the well gets broken at last."

quotation: Casus ubique valet; semper tibi pendeat hamus. Quo minime credas gurgite, piscis erit.
translation: Chance is powerful everywhere; let your hook be always hanging ready. In waters where you least think it, there will be a fish.

quotation: Cato mirari se aiebat, quod non rideret aruspex aruspicem cum videret.
translation:
Cato used to say that he was surprised that one soothsayer could keep his countenance 
when he saw another.
notes: In allusion to the barefaced manner in which they imposed upon the credulity of the multitude.

quotation: Catulae dominas imitantes.
translation: Puppies imitating their mistresses.
notes: Said of servants affecting the state and grandeur of their masters, and acting "high life below stairs."

quotation: Catus amat pisces, sed non vult tingere plantas.
translation: Puss loves fish, but is loth to wet her feet.
notes: It wisely "lets 'I dare not' wait upon 'I would.'" A mediaeval adage.

quotation: Caudae pilos equino paulatim oportet evellere.
translation: You must pluck out the hairs of a horse's tail one by one.
notes: Many things can be effected by patience and perseverance, which are proof against the efforts of violence and precipitation.

quotation: Causa latet, vis est notissima.
translation: The cause lies hid, the power is most evident.
notes: The evil is unseen, but its mischievous effects cannot be overlooked.

quotation: Causam hanc justam esse in arnimum inducite, Ut aliqua pars laboris minuatur mihi.
translation: For my sake come to the conclusion that this request is fair, that so some portion of my labour may be abridged.

quotation: Cautus enim metuit foveam lupus, accipiterque Suspectos laqueos, et opertum miluus hamum.
translation: For the cautious wolf dreads the pit, the hawk the suspected snare, and the fish the concealed hook.

quotation: Cave a signatis.
translation: Beware of those who are branded.
notes: Avoid bad company.

quotation: Cave ne quid stulte, ne quid temere, dicas aut facias contra potentes.
translation: Beware that you neither say nor do anything rashly against the powerful.

quotation: Cave sis te superare servum siris faciendo bene.
translation: Take care that you do not let your servant excel you in doing well.

quotation: Cave tibi a cane muto et aqua silenti.
translation: Have a care of a silent dog and a still water.

quotation: Caveat emptor; qui ignorare non debuit quod jus alienum emit.
translation: Let the buyer be on his guard: for he ought not to plead ignorance that he is buying the right of another.
notes: He is bound to take all reasonable precautions in such a case, and will be supposed to have seen all patent defects.

quotation: Cavendum est ne assentatoribus patefaciamus aures.
translation: We must be careful not to give ear to flatterers.

quotation: Cavendum est ne major poena, quam culpa, sit; et ne iisdem de causis alii plectantur, alii ne appellentur quidem.
translation:
Care must be taken that the penalty does not exceed 
the fault, and that some are not punished for the same offences for which others are not so much as called upon to answer.

quotation: Cedant arma togae, concedat laurea linguae.
translation: Let the sword give place to the gown, the laurel yield to the tongue.
notes:
Let violence give place to law and justice, the 
sword of the conqueror to the eloquence of the orator.

quotation: Cedant carminibus reges, regumque triumphi.
translation: Let kings, and the triumphs of kings, yield to verse.

quotation: Cedat uti conviva satur.
translation: Like a well-filled guest, let him depart (from life).
notes: See Cur non, &c.

quotation: Cede Deo.
translation: Yield to God.
notes: Submit to the decrees of Providence.

quotation: Cede repugnanti; cedendo victor abibis.
translation: Give way to your opponent; by yielding you will come off victorious.
notes:
A prudent concession will often secure for us 
greater advantages than an obstinate assertion of our rights.

quotation: Cedite Romani scriptores, cedite Graii.
translation: Yield, ye Roman writers; give way, ye Greeks:
notes:
ironically applied to a conceited scribbler, such for instance as Zoilus, the 
sour critic of Homer.

quotation: Cedunt grammatici, vincuntur rhetores.
translation: The grammarians give way, the rhetoricians are vanquished.

quotation: Celsae graviore casu Decidunt turres.
translation: Lofty towers fall down with the greatest crash.
notes: The greater the elevation, the heavier the fall.

quotation: Centum doctum hominum consilia sola haec devincit dea Fortuna.
translation: This goddess, Fortune, unaided, prevails over the plans of a hundred learned men.

quotation: Centum solatia curae Et rus, et comites, et via longa dabunt.
translation: The country, and companions, and the length of the journey, will afford a thousand solaces for your cares.

quotation: Cepi corpus.
translation: I have taken the body.
notes: The return made by the sheriff upon a capias, or other similar process.

quotation: Cererem pro frugibus, Liberum pro vino, Neptunum pro mari, Curiam pro senatu, Campum pro comitiis, togam pro pace, arma ac tela pro bello appellare solent.
translation:
They are 
in the habit of using the word 'Ceres' for fruits, 'Bacchus' for wine, 'Neptune' for the sea, 'Curia' for the senate, 'Campus' (Martius) for civic elections, 'Toga' 
for peace, and 'arms' and 'weapons' for war.
notes: Examples of the figure Metonymy.

quotation: Cereus in vitium flecti, monitoribus asper.
translation: (Youth), pliable as wax to the bent of vice, rough to its reprovers.

quotation: Cernis, ut ignavum corrumpant otia corpus; Ut capiant vitium, ni moveantur, aquae.
translation: You see how ease enervates the slothful body; how water contracts a taint if it remains unmoved.

quotation: Cernite sim qualis; qui modo qualis eram.
translation: Behold what I am; and what I was but a little while ago!

quotation: Cernuntur in agendo virtutes.
translation: The virtues of a man are seen in his actions.

quotation: Certa amittimus, dum incerta petimus.
translation: We lose what is certain, while we are seeking what is uncertain.

quotation: Certa sunt paucis.
translation: There is certainty in few words.
notes: This, however, may admit of some doubt.

quotation: Certe ego fecissem, nec sum sapientior illo.
translation: At all events I should have done so, and I am no wiser than he.

quotation: Certe ignoratio futurorum malorum utilior est quam scientia.
translation: Assuredly the ignorance of future evils is preferable to the knowledge of them.
notes: To much the same effect as our proverb. "What the eye don't see the heart don't grieve." "Where ignorance is bliss," &c.

quotation: Certiorari.
translation: To be made more certain.
notes: A writ from the Court of Chancery, or Queen's Bench, commanding the judges of the inferior courts to certify or to return the records of a cause pending before them.

quotation: Certis rebus certa signa praecurrunt.
translation: Certain signs precede certain events.
notes: This reminds us of Campbell's line, "Coming events cast their shadow before."

quotation: Certum est quod certum reddi potest.
translation: That is certain which is capable of being made certain.

quotation: Certum voto pete finem.
translation: To your wishes fix a certain end.

quotation: Cervi, luporum praeda rapacium, Sectamur ultro, quos opimus Fallere et effugere est triumphus.
translation: We, like stags, the prey of rapacious wolves, follow on our own accord those, whom to deceive and escape would be a signal triumph.

quotation: Cessante causa, cessat et effectus.
translation: The cause removed, the effect ceases also.

quotation: Chius dominum emit.
translation: The Chian buys himself a master.
notes: This adage was used in reference to those who bring calamities on themselves. When Chios was conquered by Mithridates, he delivered the inhabitants into the hands of the slaves, whom they themselves had imported.

quotation: Christe eleison.
translation: Christ have mercy upon us.
notes: Latinized Greek, used in the service of the Romish Church. See Kyrie eleison.

quotation: Chronica si penses, cum pugnant Oxonienses, Post paucos menses, volat ira per Angliginenses.
translation: If you examine the chronicles, when the Oxford men fall out, within a few months the strife will fly throughout all England.
notes: A monkish Leonine proverb in reference to the numerous strifes and dissensions which arose at Oxford during the middle ages.

quotation: Circuitus verborum.
translation: A round-about expression.
notes: A rambling story.

quotation: Citius quam asparagi coquuntur.
translation: Quicker than you could cook asparagus.
notes: A proverb frequently used by the emperor Augustus, when he wanted anything to be done instantly.

quotation: Citius venit periculum cum contemnitur.
translation: When danger is despised, it overtakes us all the sooner.
notes: An enemy despised is the most dangerous enemy of all.

quotation: Cito maturum cito putridum.
translation: Soon ripe, soon rotten.
notes: A proverb in dispraise of precocity. See Odi puerulos, &c.

quotation: Cito scribendo non fit ut bene scribatur, bene scribendo fit ut cito.
translation: In writing readily, it does not follow that you write well, but in writing well, you must be able to write readily.
notes: See Sat cito, &c.

quotation: Citra pulverem.
translation: "Without dust," i.e. "without labour."
notes: The ancient wrestlers, after anointing themselves, sprinkled their bodies with fine dust, to stop the pores and prevent exhaustion by too great perspiration.

quotation: Cives magistratibus pareant, magistratus legibus.
translation: Let the citizens obey the magistrates, the magistrates the laws.

quotation: Civitas ea autem in libertale est posita, quae suis stat viribus, non ex alieno arbitrio pendet.
translation: That nation is in the enjoyment of liberty which stands by its own strength, and does not depend on the will of another.

quotation: Clamato, Meus est hic ager, ille tuus.
translation: Cry aloud, 'This is my land, that is yours.'

quotation: Clarum et venerabile nomen Gentibus, et multum nostrae quod proderat urbi.
translation: A name illustrious and revered by nations, and one that has advantaged our city much.
notes: Said of Cato of Utica.

quotation: Claudicantis conversatione utens, ipse quoque claudicare disces.
translation: Associate with the lame and you will learn to limp.
notes: To the same effect as the line quoted by St. Paul from the Greek, "Evil communications corrupt good manners." We have a very similar proverb, "Tell me your company, and I will tell you what you are."

quotation: Claudite jam rivos, sat prata biberunt.
translation: Now close your streams, the meadows have imbibed enough.
notes: Alluding to irrigation of the fields, but figuratively meaning, "Cease the song," or " conversation," as the case may be.

quotation: Clausam fregit.
translation: He broke into my enclosure.
notes: An action of trespass committed on lands or tenements.

quotation: Clavam extorquere Herculi.
translation: To wrest his club from Hercules.
notes: To attempt to do a thing which is far beyond our capacity.

quotation: Clericus, vel addiscens.
translation: Either a clerk, or learning to be one.
notes: A mediaeval expression, used with reference to a man who wishes to appear very knowing.

quotation: Clodius accusat maechos.
translation: Clodius accuses the adulterers.
notes: Clodius himself was one of the greatest profligates of his age. Hence these words became a proverb, like our saying, "The devil rebukes sin."

quotation: Coelo tegitur qui non habet urnam.
translation: He is covered by the heavens who has no urn.

quotation: Coelum ipsum petimus stultitia.
translation: We aim at heaven even in our folly.
notes: Said in allusion to the Fable of the Giants attempting to seize heaven, and the restless spirit of man.

quotation: Coelum non animum mutant qui trans mare currunt.
translation:
Those who cross the sea, change their clime but not 
their character.

quotation: Coepisti melius quam desinis; ultima primis Cedunt: dissimiles hic vir, et ille puer.
translation: With more honour didst thou begin, than thou dost close; the last scene falls short of the first: how unlike the present man and the child of that day!

quotation: Coetus dulces, valete!
translation: Happy meetings, fare ye well!

quotation: Cogenda mens est ut incipiat.
translation: The mind must be excited to make a beginning.
notes:
The great difficulty in 
most things is how to make a beginning, hence the saying, "A thing begun, is half done."

quotation: Cogi qui potest nescit mori.
translation: He who can be compelled knows not how to die.
notes: A man who, upon compulsion, will do that which is dishonourable, is afraid to meet death, the other alternative.

quotation: Cogitato, mus pusillus quam sit sapiens bestia, Aetatem qui uni cubili nunquam committit suam.
translation: Consider the little mouse, what a sagacious animal it is, for it never intrusts its life to one hole only.

quotation: Cognatio movet invidiam.
translation: Relationship gives rise to envy.
notes: We are more apt to envy the good fortune of our relatives than that of strangers.

quotation: Cognovit actionem.
translation: He has confessed the action.
notes:
The case is so called where a defendant confesses 
the plaintiff's cause against him to be true, and suffers judgment to be entered against him without trial.

quotation: Collectumque fremens volvit sub naribus ignem.
translation: And snorting, rolls the volumes of fire beneath his nostrils.

quotation: Colubram in sinu fovere.
translation: To cherish a serpent in one's bosom.
notes: To admit into your confidence a false friend, or  as we call him, "a snake in the grass."

quotation: Comes jucundus in via pro vehiculo est.
translation: A pleasant companion, upon a journey, is as good as a carriage.
notes: Because he will shorten the journey by beguiling the time.

quotation: Comis et humanus erga alios.
translation: One courteous and humane towards others.

quotation: Comis in uxorem.
translation: A man attentive to his wife.

quotation: Comitas inter gentes.
translation: Comity between nations.
notes:
Courtesy in their intercourse, and consideration for the interests 
and feelings of each other. It is this comity that renders sacred between belligerents the flag of truce.

quotation: Commodum ex injuria sua nemo habere debet.
translation: No man ought to derive advantage from his own wrong.

quotation: Commota fervet plebecula bile.
translation: Its anger moved, the rabble is excited.

quotation: Commune bonum.
translation: A common good.

quotation: Commune periculum concordiam parit.
translation: A common danger produces unanimity.

quotation: Commune naufragium omnibus est consolatio.
translation: A general shipwroek is a consolation to all.
notes: A general calamity, when all row in the same boat, is borne with mora firmness of mind, by each individual, than a similar misfortune would have been, had it happened to himself alone.

quotation: Commune vitium in magnis liberisque civitatibus ut invidia comes gloriae sit.
translation:
It is a common vice in 
great and free states, for envy to be the attendant upon glory,
notes: ‚Äî especially in Athens, where Aristides became hated, because he had deserved to be called "the Just."

quotation: Communia proprie dicere.
translation: To express common-place things with propriety.

quotation: Communibus annis.
translation: One year with another.

quotation: Communis utilitas societatis maximum vinculum eat.
translation: The common good is the great chain which binds men together in society.

quotation: Communiter negligitur, quod communiter possidetur.
translation: That is neglected by all, which is possessed by all.
notes: Every man's business is nobody's business.

quotation: Componitur orbis Regis ad exemplum; nec sic inflectere sensus Humanos edictu valent, quam vita regentis.
translation: The manners of the world are formed after the example of the king; nor can edicts influence the human understanding, so much as the life of the ruler.

quotation: Compositum miraculi causa.
translation: A story trumped up for the sake of exciting wonder.
notes: Much like what we call a "cock and bull story."

quotation: Compos mentis.
translation: In the enjoyment of his understanding.

quotation: Conciliat animos comitas affabilitasque sermonis.
translation: Courtesy and affability of address conciliate the feelings.

quotation: Concordia discors.
translation: A discordant concord.
notes: Expressive of a harmonious union of things of different natures.

quotation: Concordia res parvae crescunt, discordia maximae dilabuntur.
translation: With concord, from small beginnings things increase; with discord, the greatest advantages are frittered away.
notes: The former part of this quotation is the motto of the corporation of the Merchant Tailors.

quotation: Condo et compono quae mox depromere possim.
translation: I store and lay by things which I may be enabled one day to draw upon.
notes: In my hours of study I gain knowledge, which is to be useful to me in after-life.

quotation: Confirmat usum qui tollit abusum.
translation: He confirms the use of a thing, who takes away the abuse.

quotation: Confiteor, si quid prodest delicta fateri.
translation: I confess my errors, if it is of any use to acknowledge them.

quotation: Conjugium vocat, hoc praetexit nomine culpam.
translation: She calls it wedlock, by this name she glosses over her fault.
notes: The unfortunate Dido is not the only one who on such an occasion has laid the same "flattering unction to her soul.

quotation: Conscia mens recti famae mendacia risit; Sed nos in vitium credula turba sumus.
translation: Her mind, conscious of integrity, laughed to scorn the falsehoods of report; but we are, all of us, a set too ready to believe ill.

quotation: Conscientia mille testes.
translation: The conscience is as good as a thousand witnesses.

quotation: Conscientia rectae voluntatis maxima consolatio est rerum incommodarum.
translation: A consciousness of good intentions is a very great consolation in misfortunes.

quotation: Consensus facit legem.
translation: Consent makes the law.
notes: Two parties having made an agreement with their eyes open, and without fraud, the law will insist on its being carried out.

quotation: Consentientes et agentes pari poena plectentur.
translation:
Those who consent to the act, and those who commit 
it, should be visited with equal punishment.
notes: See Qui facit, &c.

quotation: Consentire non videtur qui errat.
translation: He who is under a mistake is not considered to consent.
notes: No one, in law, is deemed to consent to that of which he had not a previous knowledge. But every man is supposed to know the law, and "ignorantia legis non excusat." See Nil volitum, &c.

quotation: Consilia firmiora sunt de divinis locis.
translation: Advice is given with higher sanction from holy places.

quotation: Consilia qui dant prava cautis hominibus, Et perdunt operam et deridentur turpiter.
translation: Those who give bad advice to discreet persons, both lose their pains and, to their disgrace, are laughed to scorn.

quotation: Consilium Pompeii plane Themistocleum est; putat enim, qui mari potitur, eum rerum potiri.
translation: The plan of Pompey is clearly that of Themistocles; for he thinks that he who gains the command of the sea, must obtain the supreme power.

quotation: Conspicit arcem, Ingeniis, opibusque, et festa pace virentem.
translation: She looks upon the citadel, flourishing in arts, in wealth, and joyous peace.

quotation: Constans et lenis, ut res expostulet, esto.
translation: Be firm or mild, as circumstances may require.

quotation: Constiterant hinc Thisbe, Pyramus illinc, Inque vicem fuerat captatus anhelitus oris.
translation: They took their stations, Thisbe on the one side, and Pyramus on the other, and the breath of their mouths was mutually caught by turns.

quotation: Constructio legis non facit injuriam.
translation: The construction of the law does no injury.

quotation: Consuefacere aliquem sua sponte recte facere quam alieno metu.
translation: To teach a person to act correctly of his own accord, rather than through fear of another.

quotation: Consuetudine animus rursus te huc inducet.
translation: Through habit your inclination will be leading you to do it again.

quotation: Consuetudinem benignitatis, largitioni munerum antepono. Haec est gravium hominum atque magnorum; illa quasi assentatorum populi, multitudinis levitatem voluptate quasi titillantium.
translation: I prefer much the habit of courtesy to the bestowing of contributions. The one is in the power of men of eminence and high character; the other belongs to the flatterers of the populace, who in a manner tickle and delight the multitude thereby.

quotation: Consuetudo est altera natura.
translation: Use is second nature.

quotation: Consuetudo est altera lex.
translation: Usage is a second law.

quotation: Consuetudo est optimus interpres legum.
translation: Custom is the best interpreter of the laws.

quotation: Consuetudo pro lege servatur.
translation: Custom is held as law.
notes: Usage from time immemorial is the basis of our common law.

quotation: Consule de gemmis, de tincta murice lana, Consule de facie corporibusque diem.
translation: Consult the daylight about gems, about wool dyed in purple; consult it about the face and the figure as well.

quotation: Consummatum est.
translation: It is finished.

quotation: Contemni est gravius stultitiae quam percuti.
translation:
To a foolish man, it is more bitter to be treated with contempt, than 
to receive a blow.

quotation: Contemni se impatienter ferunt principes, quippe qui coli consueverunt.
translation:
Princes, because they have been 
accustomed to receive homage, can ill brook being treated with contempt.

quotation: Contemnuntur ii qui nec sibi, nec alteri prosunt, ut dicitur; in quibus nullus labor, nulla industria, nulla cura est.
translation: They are to be despised, who neither profit themselves nor others, as the saying is; in whom there is no exertion, no industry, no thought.

quotation: Contemporanea expositio est fortissima in lege.
translation: A contemporary exposition prevails in law.
notes: A precedent drawn from the established practice of the time, when the law was promulgated, being made in accordance with the then prevailing notions and usages, ought to have the most force.

quotation: Contigimus portum, quo mihi cursus erat.
translation: I have reached the harbour, to which I steered my course.

quotation: Continuo culpam ferro compesce, priusquam Dira per incautum serpant contagia vulgus.
translation: Instantly repress the mischief with the knife, before the dire contagion has infected the unthinking multitude.
notes: Even among civilized nations, we see life sacrificed for the common good.

quotation: Contra bonos mores.
translation: Contrary to good manners,
notes: or morals.

quotation: Contra malum mortis, non est medicamen in hortis.
translation:
Against the evil of death there is no remedy in 
gardens.
notes: A Leonine line.

quotation: Contra stimulum calcas.
translation: You kick against the spur.
notes: So in Acts ix. 5, "It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks?" The meaning is, that you only injure yourself by resistance.

quotation: Contra verbosos noli contendere verbis; Sermo datur cunctis, animi sapientia paucis.
translation: Strive not with words against the contentious; speech is given to all, wisdom to few.

quotation: Contumeliam si dices, audies.
translation: If you utter affronting speeches, you will have to hear them.

quotation: Conveniens vitae mors fuit ista suae.
translation: That was a death conformable to his life.

quotation: Conventio privatorum non potest publico juri derogare.
translation: An agreement between private persona cannot derogate from the rights of the public.

quotation: Convivae certe tui dicant, Bibamus, moriendum est.
translation: Your guests are for saying, no doubt, 'Let us drink, for die we must.'
notes: See 1 Cor. xv. 32.

quotation: Convivatoris, uti ducis, ingenium res Adversae nudare solent, celare secundae.
translation: Untoward circumstances usually bring out the talents of a host, as they do those of a general; while everything goes on well, they lie concealed.

quotation: Cor ne edito.
translation: Eat not your heart.
notes: A figurative expression, meaning, "Do not consume your life with cares."

quotation: Coram domino rege.
translation: Before our lord the king.

quotation: Coram nobis.
translation: Before us.
notes: Before the court. Before persons invested with due authority.

quotation: Coram non judice.
translation: Before a person who is not a judge.
notes: Before a tribunal which has no jurisdiction.

quotation: Cornix scorpium rapuit.
translation: The crow seized a scorpion,
notes: and was stung to death. Mischief recoils on its author. See Neque enim. &c.

quotation: Coronat virtus cultores suos.
translation: Virtue crowns her votaries.

quotation: Corpora lente augescunt, cito extinguuntur.
translation: All bodies are slow in growth, rapid in decay.

quotation: Corpora magnanimo satis est prostrasse leoni: Pugna suum finem, cum jacet hostis, habet.
translation: It is sufficient for the noble-hearted lion to have brought the body to the ground: the contest is over when the enemy lies prostrate.
notes: The poets give the lion a better character than he really deserves.

quotation: Corpori tantum indulgeas quantum bonae valetudini satis est.
translation:
Indulge the body only so far as is necessary for 
good health.
notes: Be moderate in pleasures although harmless in themselves.

quotation: Corporis et fortunae bonorum ut initium finis est. Omnia arte occidunt, et aucta senescunt.
translation:
Of the blessings of 
health and fortune, as there is a beginning, so there is an end. Everything, as it is improved by art, hurries onward 
to decay, and increases only to become old.

quotation: Corpus adhuc Echo, non vox erat: et tamen usum Garrula non alium, quam nunc habet, oris habebat; reddere de multis ut verba novissima posset.
translation: Echo was then a body, not a mere voice; and yet the babbler had no other use of speech than she now has, to be able to repeat the last words out of many.

quotation: Corpus delicti.
translation: The body of the offence.
notes: The sum and substance of the crime.

quotation: Corpus omne sive arescit in pulverem, sive in humorem solvitur, vel in cinerem comprimitur, vel in nidorem tenuatur, subducitur nobis; sed Deo elementorum custode reservatur.
translation: (When death happens) every body is reduced to dust, dissolved into fluid, converted to ashes, or wasted away by evaporation, and so withdrawn from our sight; but it is preserved in the hands of God, the guardian of the elements.

quotation: Corpus onustum Hesternis vitiis animum quoque praegravat una.
translation: The body, oppressed by the debauch of yesterday, weighs down the mind as well.

quotation: Corpus quasi vas est aut aliquod animi receptaculum.
translation: The body is a vessel, as it were, or receptacle for the soul.

quotation: Corpus sine pectore.
translation: A body without a soul.
notes: A lump of flesh without spirit or animation. See Sine pectore corpus.

quotation: Corrumpunt bonos mores colloquia prava.
translation: Evil communications corrupt good manners.
notes: From the Greek.

quotation: Corrupti mores sunt depravatique admiratione divitiarum.
translation: Manners become corrupted and depraved through the hankering for riches.

quotation: Corruptio optimi pessima.
translation: The corruption of the best produces the worst.
notes: Nothing is so pernicious both in example and results as the rebound from very good to very bad. So our old proverb, "The sweetest wine makes the sharpest vinegar."

quotation: Corruptissima in republica plurimae leges.
translation: In the state which is the most corrupt, the laws are always the most numerous.
notes: Such a state of things necessitates a multiplicity of laws.

quotation: Cos ingeniorum.
translation: A whetstone for the wits.

quotation: Cras credemus, hodie nihil.
translation: Tomorrow we will believe, not to-day.
notes: Let us wait and see what will happen to-morrow; for the present we will sleep upon it.

quotation: Credat Judaeus Apella.
translation: Let Apella the Jew believe it.
notes: An expression used in derision of the Jews, who were held in the greatest contempt among the Romans, every vice or weakness being imputed to them.

quotation: Crede mihi bene qui latuit, bene vixit, et intra Fortunam debet quisque manere suam.
translation: Believe me, he who has the good fortune to escape notice, lives the happiest life, and every one is bound to live within his means.

quotation: Crede mihi, miseros prudentia prima relinquit.
translation: Believe me, prudence is the first thing to forsake the wretched.

quotation: Crede mihi, multos habeas cum dignus amicos, Non fuit e multis quolibet ille minor.
translation: Believe me, although you deservedly have many friends, he out of those many was inferior to none.

quotation: Crede mihi, res est ingeniosa dare.
translation: Believe me, it is a noble thing to give.

quotation: Crede quod est quod vis; ac desine tuta vereri; Deque fide certa sit tibi certa fides.
translation: Believe that that is, which thou dost wish to be; cease to fear for what is secure, and have a certain assurance of undoubted constancy.

quotation: Crede quod habes, et habes.
translation: Believe that you have it, and you have it.
notes: This is not universally true ‚Äî witness the unhappy termination of Alnaschar's reverie, whose story is told in the Spectator and the Arabian Nights.

quotation: Credebant hoc grande nefas, et morte piandum, Si juvenis vetulo non assurrexerat.
translation: They used to hold it to be a heinous sin, and one that death alone could expiate, if a young man did not rise to pay honour to an elder.

quotation: Credite, posteri!
translation: Believe it, Posterity!

quotation: Credo pudicitiam, Saturno rege, moratam In terris.
translation: In the reign of Saturn I believe that chastity did exist in the world.
notes: The reign of Saturn was the "golden age" of the Romans. Juvenal is speaking of the almost universal corruption of the Roman females in his day.

quotation: Credula res amor est.
translation: Love is a credulous thing.

quotation: Credula vitam Spes fovet, ac melius eras fore semper ait.
translation: Credulous hope cherishes life, and ever tells us that to-morrow will be better.

quotation: Crescentem sequitur cura pecuniam, Majorumque fames. Multa petentibus, Desunt multa. Bene est cui Deus obtulit Parca quod satis est manu.
translation: Care attends accumulated wealth, and a thirst for still greater riches. They who require much are always in want of much. Happy is he to whom God has given a sufficiency with a sparing hand.

quotation: Crescit amor nummi quantum ipsa pecunia crescit: Et minus hanc optat, qui non habet.
translation: The love of money increases as fast as our wealth, and he who has none wishes for it the least.

quotation: Crescit indulgens sibi dirus hydrops.
translation: The fatal dropsy nursed by self-indulgence increases apace.
notes: This figure is here used in reference to the "greed for gain."

quotation: Crescit sub pondere virtus.
translation: Virtue grows under every weight;
notes: shines forth with renewed lustre under every trial. The motto of the Earl of Denbigh.

quotation: Cressa ne careat pulchra dies nota.
translation: Let not a day so joyful be without its mark of Cretan chalk.

quotation: Creta an carbone notandum.
translation: To be marked with chalk, or with charcoal.
notes: The Romans thus distinguished their lucky and unlucky days.

quotation: Creta notare.
translation: To mark with chalk.
notes: To place a white line against the name of a person was to signify approval.

quotation: Cretizandum cum Crete.
translation: A man must be a Cretan with the Cretans.
notes: We must do at Rome as Rome does.

quotation: Creverunt et opes, et opum furiosa cupido: Et cum possideant plurima, plura volunt.
translation: Both wealth has increased, and the maddening lust for wealth: and though men possess ever so much they still wish for more.

quotation: Crimen laesae majestatis.
translation: The crime of lese majesty,
notes: which involves the guilt of high-treason.

quotation: Crimen quod mihi dabatur, crimen non erat.
translation: That which was imputed to me as a crime was no crime.

quotation: Crimina qui cernunt aliorum, non sua cernunt, Hi sapiunt aliis, desipiuntque sibi.
translation: Those who see the faults of others, do not see their own; such men are wise towards others, and fools to themselves.

quotation: Crimine ab uno Disce omnes.
translation: From one offence learn all.

quotation: Crine ruber, niger ore, brevis pede, lumine laesus: Rem magnam praestas, Zoile, si bonus es.
translation: With red hair, and tawny features, short of one foot, and blind of an eye ‚Äî you do wonders, indeed, Zoilus, if you are a good man.

quotation: Croesum, quem vox justi facunda Solonis Respicere ad longae jussit spatia ultima vitae.
translation: Croesus, whom the eloquent voice of the righteous Solon bade look upon the closing scene of a long life.
notes: See Herodotus, b. i e. 32.

quotation: Crudelem medicum intemperans aeger facit.
translation: A disobedient patient makes an unfeeling physician.
notes: Because he is obliged to have recourse to harsher measures to effect a cure.

quotation: Crudelis ubique Luctus, ubique pavor, et plurima mortis imago.
translation: Everywhere is cruel sorrow, terror on every side, and death in a thousand shapes.

quotation: Crux.
translation: A cross.
notes: Anything that frets or annoys us, a difficulty or stumblingblock is so called. Thus, crux criticorum, "the cross of critics;" crux medicorum, "the cross of physicians;" crux mathematicorum, "the cross of mathematicians."

quotation: Cucullus non facit monachum.
translation: The cowl does not make the monk.
notes: Trust not appearances.

quotation: Cui bono?
translation: For whose benefit?
notes: A maxim of Cassius, the judge, quoted by Cicero (Pro Milone). It is generally used as signifying, "What is the good of it?"

quotation: Cui famulatur maximus orbis Diva potens rerum, domitrixque pecunia fati.
translation: She to whom the great world is obedient, that goddess who rules mankind, money, the controller of fate.

quotation: Cui licet quod majus, non debet quod minus est non licere.
translation: He who has the greater right, ought not to be without the lesser one.
notes: Thus, in the transfer of property, a conveyance of the rights incident to it is always to be presumed.

quotation: Cui malo?
translation: To what evil?
notes: What harm can result from it?

quotation: Cui mens divinior atque os Magna sonaturum des nominis hujus honorem.
translation: To him who is divinely inspired, and has a command of lofty language, you may grant the honour of this title.
notes: Said in allusion to the true poet.

quotation: Cui nihil satis, huic etiam nihil turpe.
translation: Nothing will be base to him for whom nothing is enough.
notes: The man is troubled with no scruples, who covets unlimited wealth.

quotation: Cui non conveniat sua res, ut calceus olim, Si pede major erit, subvertet; si minor, uret.
translation: To him who is not satisfied with his fortune, it is as with a shoe; if it is too large for his foot it will upset him, if too small, it will pinch him.

quotation: Cui placet alterius, sua nimirum est odio sors.
translation:
When a man is captivated with the lot of another, no wonder if 
he is discontented with his own.

quotation: Cui placet, obliviscitur; cui dolet, meminit.
translation: He who is pleased at a thing, forgets it; he who is grieved at it, bears it in mind.

quotation: Cui prodest scelus, is fecit.
translation: He who profits by the villany, has perpetrated it.
notes:
This is true in reference to 
the share of criminality which attaches to the "accomplice after the fact," but is not of universal application.

quotation: Cuicunque aliquis quid concedit, concedere videtur et id, sine quo res ipsa esse non potest.
translation: He who makes a grant to another, is held to have granted that as well, without which the thing so granted cannot be enjoyed.
notes: A house or land, for instance, cannot be sold without right of ingress to it, if in the vendor's power to grant it.

quotation: Cuilibet in arte sua perito est credendum.
translation: Every man ought to have credit for skill in his own art.

quotation: Cuivis dolori remedium est patientia.
translation: Patience is the remedy for every sorrow.

quotation: Cujus conatibus obstat Res angusta domi.
translation: Whose efforts are frustrated by the narrowness of his means.
notes: The fate of too many!

quotation: Cujus est solum, ejus est usque ad caelum.
translation:
To him to whom the soil belongs, belongs everything over it,
even to the sky.
notes: The building of no man, for instance, may project over the land of his neighbour.

quotation: Cujus summa est.
translation: Of which the sum and substance is.
notes: This is the long and short of it.

quotation: Cujus tu fidem in pecunia perspexeris, Verere ei verba credere?
translation: Do you fear to trust a man with your secret, of those honesty in pecuniary matters you have had experience?

quotation: Cujus vita despicitur, restat ut ejus praedicatio contemnatur.
translation: When a man's life is despised, it follows that his preaching must fall into contempt.
notes: The necessity of supporting precept by practice.

quotation: Cujus vulturis hoc erit cadaver?
translation: To what vulture's share shall this carcass fall?

quotation: Cujuslibet rei simulator atque dissimulator.
translation: A man who possessed the power on every occasion to seem to be what he was not, and to conceal what he really was.
notes: The character of Catiline, a finished hypocrite, as portrayed by Sallust.

quotation: Cujusvis hominis est errare, nullius nisi insipientis in errore perseverare.
translation: Every man is liable to err, but it is only the part of a fool to persevere in error.

quotation: Culpa sua damnum sentiens, non intelligitur damnum pati.
translation: He who suffers a loss by his own fault, is not considered (by the law) a sufferer.

quotation: Culpam poena premit comes.
translation: Punishment follows hard upon crime.

quotation: Cultaque Judaeo septima sacra Syro.
translation: And the seventh day kept holy and observed by the Syrian Jew.

quotation: Cum domus ingenti subito mea lapsa ruina Concidit, in domini procubuitque caput.
translation: When my house came suddenly down, and fell in ruins with a tremendous crash upon its master's head.

quotation: Cum corpore mentem Crescere sentimus, pariterque senescere.
translation: We feel that the mental powers increase with those of the body, and, in like manner, grow feeble with it.

quotation: Cum dubia et fragilis sit nobis vita tributa, In morte alterius spem tu tibi ponere noli.
translation: Seeing that life has been given us precarious and full of uncertainty, fix not thy hopes on the death of another.

quotation: Cum duo inter se pugnantia reperiuntur in testamento, ultimum ratum est.
translation: When two clauses are found in a will, repugnant to each other, the last holds good.
notes: But in deeds, the first holds good.

quotation: Cum duplicantur lateres venit Moses.
translation: When the tale of bricks is doubled, then comes Moses;
notes:
to the rescue of 
the Israelites. A mediaeval proverb, meaning that, "when things are at the worst they will mend."

quotation: Cum est concupita pecunia, nec ratio sanat cupiditatem, existit morbus animi eique morbo nomen est avaritia.
translation:
When money is coveted, and the desire is not cured by reason, there is a disease of the mind, and the name of 
that disease is 'avarice.'

quotation: Cum feriunt unum, non unum fulmina terrent.
translation: When the lightning strikes but one, not one only does it alarm.

quotation: Cum fortuna manet, vultum servatis amici; Cum cedit, turpi vertitis ora fuga.
translation: While prosperity lasts, you, my friends, give me your countenance; when it fails, you turn away your faces in disgraceful flight.

quotation: Cum fortuna perit, nullus amicus erit.
translation: When fortune fails us, we shall have no friend left.

quotation: Cum fueris felix, quae sunt adversa caveto; Non eadem cursu respondent ultima primis.
translation: When you are enjoying prosperity, provide against adversity; the end of life will not be attended by the same train of fortunate circumstances as the beginning.

quotation: Cum furor haud dubius, cum sit manifesta phrenesis, Ut locuples moriaris, egentis vivere fato.
translation: Since it is undoubted madness, manifest insanity, to live the life of a beggar that you may die rich.

quotation: Cum grano salis.
translation: With a grain of salt.
notes: With something which will help us to swallow it; with some latitude or allowance. Said of anything to which we are unable to give implicit credence.

quotation: Cum larvis luctari.
translation: To wrestle with ghosts.
notes: To speak ill of the dead. See De mortuis, &c.

quotation: Cum licet fugere ne quaere litem.
translation: When you can escape it, avoid a law-suit.

quotation: Cum lux altera venit, Jam eras hesternum consumpsimus; ecce aliud cras Egerit hos annos.
translation: When another day arrives, we have consumed the morrow of yesterday; behold, another morrow comes, and so wastes our years.
notes: A censure against procrastination, "the thief of time."

quotation: Cum magna malae superest audacia causae, Creditur a multis fiducia.
translation: When a bad cause is backed by great impudence, it is believed by many to be the boldness of innocence.

quotation: Cum magnis virtutibus affers Grande supercilium.
translation: With thy high virtues thou dost bring great superciliousness.

quotation: Cum moritur dives concurrunt undique cives; Pauperis ad funus vix est e millibus unus.
translation: When a rich man dies, the citizens flock together from every side; at a poor man's funeral there is hardly one out of thousands.
notes: Mediaeval Leonine lines.

quotation: Cum multis aliis, quae nunc perscribere longum est.
translation: With many other things which it would now be tedious to set forth in writing.
notes: A line often used in an ironical sense. To whom does it belong?

quotation: Cum plus sint potae, plus potiuntur aquae.
translation: The more water is drunk, the more is desired.
notes: See Quo plus, &c.

quotation: Cum prostrata sopore Urget membra quies, et mens sine pondere ludit.
translation: When repose steals over the limbs, extended in sleep, and the mind disports without restraint.

quotation: Cum pulchris tunicis sumet nova consilia et spes.
translation: Happy in his fine clothes, he will adopt new plans and cherish fresh hopes.

quotation: Cum surges abitura domum, surgemus et omnes.
translation: When you rise to go home, we will all rise too.

quotation: Cum tabulis animum censoris sumat honesti.
translation: Let him, with his papers, assume the spirit of an honest critic.

quotation: Cum tristibus severe, cum remissis jucunde, cum senibus graviter, cum juventute comiter vive.
translation: With those who are of a gloomy turn, be serious; with the idle, be cheerful; with the old, be grave; and with the young, be gay.

quotation: Cum volet illa dies, quae nil nisi corporis hujus Jus habet, incerti spatium mihi finiat aevi.
translation: Let that day, which has no power but over this body of mine, put an end to the term of my uncertain life, when it will.

quotation: Cuncta prius tentata: sed immedicabile vulnus Ense recidendum, ne pars sincera trahatur.
translation: All methods have been already tried; but a wound that admits of no cure must be cut away, that the sounder parts may not be corrupted.

quotation: Cunctando restituit rem.
translation: He saved the state by delay.
notes: Said in praise of Fabius, who saved Rome by avoiding an engagement with Hannibal.

quotation: Cuncti adsint, meritaeque expectent praemia palmae.
translation: Let all attend, and await the reward of well-earned laurels.

quotation: Cunctis servatorem liberatoremque acclamantibus.
translation: All hailing him as their saviour and deliverer.

quotation: Cupido dominandi cunctis affectibus flagrantior est.
translation: The desire of rule is the most powerful of all the affections of the mind.

quotation: Cur ante tubam tremor occupat artus?
translation: Why does tremor seize the limbs before the trumpet sounds?
notes: That is, before the signal for battle.

quotation: Cur in theatrum, Cato severe, venisti?
translation: Why, Cato, with all thy gravity, didst thou come to the theatre?
notes:
On the occasion of the indecent celebration of the Floralia, when he only came that he might be seen to depart. 
See An ideo, &c. (App.)

quotation: Cur indecores in limine primo Deficimus?
translation: Why faint we inglorious at the very outset?

quotation: Cur me querelis exanimas tuis?
translation: Why worry me to death with your complaints?

quotation: Cur moriatur homo, cut salvia crescit in horto?
type: maxim of the School of Health at Salerno
translation: Why should the man die in whose garden sage grows?
notes: "He that would live for aye, Must eat sage in May." Sage is a good stomachic, and its medicinal qualities were highly valued in former times. It is said to have derived its name from the Latin salvus, "safe," or "healthy."

quotation: Cur moriatur homo qui sumit de cinamomo?
type: maxim of the School of Health at Salerno
translation: Why should the man die who takes cinnamon?

quotation: Cur nescire, pudens prave, quam discere malo?
translation: Why do I prefer, through false modesty, to be ignorant rather than learn?

quotation: Cur non, ut plenus vitae conviva, recedis? Aequo animoque capis securam, stulte, quietem.
translation: Why not, fool, like a well-filled guest at life's banquet, withdraw, and, with contented mind, take a repose that is removed from every care?

quotation: Cur opus affectas, ambitiose, novum.
translation: Why, in your ambition, do you attempt a new task?

quotation: Cura esse quod audis.
translation: Take care to be as good as you are esteemed to be.

quotation: Cura ut valeas.
translation: Take care of your health.

quotation: Cura pii Dis sunt.
translation: The good are the care the gods.

quotation: Curae est sua cuique voluptas.
translation: His own gratification is the object of each.

quotation: Curae leves loquuntur, ingentes stupent.
translation: Light grief find utterance, deeper ones are dumb.

quotation: Curas tolle graves, irasci crede profanum.
translation: Dispel anxious cares; consider it profane to be angry.

quotation: Curatio funeris, conditio sepulturae, pompae exequiarum, magi sunt vivorum solatia, quam subsidia mortuorum.
translation: The arrangements of the funeral, the place of burial, the procession and the ceremonial, are rather a consolation to the living, than of importance to the dead.

quotation: Curia advisare vult.
translation: The court wishes to advise thereon.
notes: The entry made when the court takes time to deliberate before giving judgment.

quotation: Curia pauperibus clausa est; dat census honores.
translation: To the poor the senate-house is closed; wealth confers honours.

quotation: Currente calamo.
translation: With a running pen.
notes: The ancients sometimes wrote with a reed, whence this phrase. Equivalent to our English term, "off-hand."

quotation: Currus bovem trahit.
translation: The chariot is drawing the ox.
notes: "The cart is put before the horse." Said of anything done preposterously, or out of place.

quotation: Curtae nescio quid semper abest rei.
translation: There is a something, I know not what, always found wanting in every man's too meagre fortunes.

quotation: Custos morum.
translation: The guardian of morality.
notes: A magistrate is so called.

quotation: Custos regni.
translation: The guardian of the realm.
notes: A person appointed to perform the sovereign's duties in his absence.

quotation: Custos rotulorum.
translation: The master of the rolls.
notes: The principal justice of the peace in a county is also so called.

quotation: Cutem gerit laceratam canis mordax.
translation: A snapping dog wears a torn skin.
notes: "Those who in quarrels interpose, Must often wipe a bloody nose." Gay.

quotation: Cutis vulpina consuenda est cum cute leonis.
translation: The fox's skin should be sewed to that of the lion.
notes: Where the strength of the lion fails, the cunning of the fox may prevail.

quotation: Cymini sectores.
translation: Splitters of cummin-seeds,
notes: or, as we say, "splitters of straws." An expression borrowed from Aristotle. Learned triflers, like many of the schoolmen of the middle ages.

quotation: D. D. for Dono dedit.
translation: "Has presented," or " has given."

quotation: D. D. D.
translation: In presentation copies of books, these letters are inserted after the name of the giver, meaning either  donum dat, dicatque, "presents (this book), and dedicates it;" or else, dat, donat, dicatque ‚Äî "gives, presents, and dedicates (this book)."

quotation: D. M. for Dis Manibus.
translation: "To the divine Manes," or "shades of the dead." The usual commencement of Roman sepulchral inscriptions.

quotation: D. O. M.
translation: See Deo optimo maximo.

quotation: D. V.
translation: See Deo volente.

quotation: Da juranti veniam.
translation: Pardon the oath.
notes: Forgive me for swearing.

quotation: Da locum melioribus.
translation: Give way to your betters.
notes: The same maxim of modesty is inculcated by our Saviour, in Luke xiv. 8.

quotation: Da mihi mutuum testimonium.
translation: Give me your testimony, and I'll do as much for you.
notes: Claw me, and I'll claw thee.

quotation: Da modo lucra mihi, da facto gaudia lucro; Et face ut emptori verba dedisse juvet.
translation: Do but grant me profit, give me the delight that arises from making a bargain, and grant that it may prove to my advantage to have imposed upon my customers.
notes: The prayer of a fraudulent tradesman to Mercury.

quotation: Da, Pater, augustam menti conscendere sedem; Da fontem lustrare boni; da, luce reperta, In te conspicuos animi defigere visus!
translation: Grant, Father, that my mind may climb to thy august abode; grant that it may survey the source of good; grant that, when it has gained the light, I may fix my full gaze on thee!

quotation: Da populo, da verba mihi; sine nescius errem.
translation: Deceive the public, deceive me too; in my ignorance let me be mistaken.

quotation: Da, precor, ingenio praemia digna meo.
translation: Grant, I pray, a reward worthy of my genius.

quotation: Da spatium tenuemque moram, male cuncta ministrat Impetus.
translation: Allow time and a short delay, haste and violence mar everything.

quotation: Da veniam lacrymis.
translation: Grant pardon to these tears.

quotation: Dabit Deus his quoque finem.
translation: God will grant an end to even these misfortunes.
notes: A phrase generally applied to public calamities, and the only real consolation that they will admit of.

quotation: Damna minus consueta movent.
translation: Misfortunes to which we are used affect us less severely.
notes:
To the same 
effect is our vulgar adage ‚Äî "Eels become accustomed to skinning."

quotation: Damnant quod non intelligunt.
translation: They condemn what they do not understand.
notes: They make up by positiveness of assertion for lack of real knowledge.

quotation: Damnosa haereditas.
translation: A losing property.
notes: A property, the possession of which entails loss on the owner.

quotation: Damnosa quid non imminuit dies?
translation: What does not all-destructive time impair?

quotation: Damnosa senem juvat alea, ludit et haeres.
translation:
If the destructive dice have pleasures for the father, his son 
will be a gamester.
notes: So our proverb, "Bad hen, bad eggs." See Mala gallina, &c.

quotation: Damnum absque injuria.
translation: Loss without injury.
notes:
That kind of loss which all persons are liable to, 
who are exposed to the competition of others in the same business or profession as themselves. Loss, in fact, by fair competition.

quotation: Damnum appellandum est cum mala, fama lucrum.
translation: That ought to be called a loss, which is gained by the sacrifice of character.

quotation: Dapes inemptae.
translation: Dainties unbought.
notes: The produce of the farm.

quotation: Dapibus supremi Grata testudo Jovis.
translation: The shell so loved at the feasts of supreme Jove.
notes: Mercury framed the cithara, (the origin of the modern guitar,) by stretching strings across the shell of a tortoise; his music was in high requisition at the table of Jupiter.

quotation: Dare jura maritis.
translation: To lay down laws for husbands.

quotation: Dare pondus idonea fumo.
translation: Things suited to give weight to smoke.
notes: To impart value to that which is worthless.

quotation: Dat Deus immiti cornua curta bovi.
translation: God gives short horns to the vicious ox.
notes: "God sends a curst cow short horns." Much Ado About Nothing, act ii. sc. 1.

quotation: Dat inania verba, Dat sine mente sonum.
translation: He utters empty words, he utters sounds without meaning.

quotation: Dat veniam corvis, vexat censura columbas.
translation: He grants pardon to the ravens, but visits with heavy censure the doves.
notes: A line often used to signify that the innocent man meets with injustice, while the guilty escape without censure.

quotation: Data tempore prosunt, Et data non apto tempore vina nocent.
translation: Wine given at a proper time, is useful; given at an improper time, it is injurious.

quotation: Date obulum Belisario.
translation: Give your mite to Belisarius.
notes: It is said that this great general, when blind and aged, was neglected by the emperor Justinian, and obliged to beg for charity. The tale is however treated as a fiction by Gibbon.

quotation: Datur ignis, tametsi ab inimicis petas.
translation: Fire is granted, even though you ask it of your enemies.
notes: It was considered unlucky to refuse fire to any one.

quotation: Davus sum, non Oedipus.
translation: I am Davus, not Oedipus.
notes: I am a plain, simple man, not a conjuror. Oedipus was said to have solved the riddle of the Sphinx.

quotation: De alieno corio liberalis.
translation: Liberal of another man's leather.

quotation: De alieno largitor, et sui restrictus.
translation: A bestower of other men's property, but tenacious of his own.
notes: One who is liberal, but at the expense of others.

quotation: De asini umbra disceptare.
translation: To dispute about an ass's shadow.
notes: To give one's attention to frivolous matters.

quotation: De bene esse.
translation: As being well done for the present.
notes:
A thing is done de bene esse, when it is done conditionally, and is to stand good till some time named, when the question of its being rightly or wrongly done will be determined. Depositions are often taken de bene esse, the question as to whether they shall be used for the benefit of the party so taking them, being reserved for 
consideration at a future time.

quotation: De calceo sollicitus, at pedem nihil curans.
translation: Anxious about the shoe, but careless about the foot.
notes: Said of those who are more thoughtful about outside appearances than the cultivation of the mind.

quotation: De duro est ultima ferro. Fugere pudor, verumque, fidesque: In quorum subiere locum fraudesque, dolique, Insidiaeque, et vis, et amor sceleratus habendi.
translation: The last age was of hard iron. ‚Äî Modesty, and truth, and honour took to flight; in place of which succeeded fraud, deceit, treachery, violence, and the cursed hankering for acquisition.
notes: The condition of man after the fall, according to heathen tradition.

quotation: De facto.
translation: From the thing done.
notes: Because it is so. An usurper holds a throne de facto, not by right, but might.

quotation: De fumo disceptare.
translation: To dispute about smoke.
notes: To wrangle about trifles. See De asini, &c.

quotation: De fumo in flammam.
translation: Out of the smoke into the flame.
notes: Quoted by Ammianus Marcellinus. Similar to our proverb, "Out of the frying-pan," &c.

quotation: De gustibus non est disputandum.
translation: There is no disputing about tastes.
notes: Like our saying, "What is one man's meat is another man's poison."

quotation: De hoc multi multa, omnes aliquid, nemo satis.
translation: Of this matter many people have said many things, all something, no one enough.

quotation: De jure.
translation: From what is lawful, or "by law."
notes: Possession de jure is possession by right of law.

quotation: De lana caprina.
translation: About goat's wool.
notes: About a worthless object.

quotation: De male quaesitis vix gaudet tertius haeres.
translation: A third heir seldom enjoys property dishonestly got.
notes: Hence the saying, "Badly got, badly gone." See male parta, &c.

quotation: De medietate linguae.
translation: Of a moiety of languages.
notes: A jury empannelled to try a foreigner, when, at his request, one half of it is composed of foreigners, is a jury de medietate linguae.

quotation: De mendico male meretur, qui ei dat quod edat, aut quod bibat, Nam et illud quod dat perdit, et illi producit vitam ad miseriam.
translation: He deserves ill of a beggar, who gives him to eat or to drink; for he both loses that which he gives, and prolongs for the other a life of misery.

quotation: De minimis non curat lex.
translation: The law takes no notice of extreme trifles.
notes: The theft of a pin, for instance.

quotation: De missa ad mensam.
translation: From mass to table, or, to preserve the jingle, "From mass to mess."
notes: A mediaeval saying, implying that the only active employment of the monks was to eat and say their prayers.

quotation: De mortuis nil nisi bonum.
translation: Of the dead be nothing said but what is good.
notes: Silence, at least, is a duty where we cannot praise the dead.

quotation: De motu proprio.
translation: From his own impulse.
notes: "Of his own free will."

quotation: De multis grandis acervus erit.
translation: Out of many things a large heap is made.

quotation: De nihilo nihil, in nihilum nil posse reverti.
translation: From nothing there is nothing made, and no existing thing can be reduced to nothing.
notes: The doctrine of the Epicureans as to the eternity of matter. See Lucretius, B. i. l. 160‚Äî265.

quotation: De non apparentibus, et non existentibus, eadem est ratio.
translation: The reasoning is the same as to things which do not appear, and those which do not exist.

quotation: De omnibus rebus, et quibusdam aliis.
translation: About everything, and something more besides.
notes: Said ironically of a voluminous book, or of a speech in which numerous topics are discussed. The saying is said to have derived its origin from the circumstance that Smalgruenius first wrote a work entitled De omnibus rebus, and then another, De quibusdam aliis. The same story has, however, been fathered on Thomas Aquinas.

quotation: De paupertate tacentes Plus poscente ferent.
translation: Those who are silent as to their poverty will obtain more than he who begs.
notes: So the lion rewarded the modest traveller, and rebuffed the importunate robber. See Phaedrus' Fables, B. II. Fab. I.

quotation: De pilo, or de filo, pendet.
translation: It hangs by a hair, or "by a thread."
notes: The risk, or danger, is imminent. Originally said in reference to the sword which Dionysius of Syracuse caused to be suspended over the head of the courtier Damocles.

quotation: De quo libelli in celeberrimis locis proponuntur, huic ne perire quidem tacite conceditur.
translation: The man who is publicly arraigned is not allowed even to be ruined in quiet.

quotation: De vita hominis nulla cunctatio longa est.
translation: When the life of a man is at stake, no delay can be too long.
notes: See Audi, nulla, &c.

quotation: Debetis velle quae velimus.
translation: You ought to wish as we wish.

quotation: Debile principium melior fortuna sequetur.
translation: Better fortune will succeed a weak beginning.

quotation: Debilem facito manu, Debilem pede, coxa, Lubricos quate dentes, Vita dum superest, bene est.
source: seneca (a portion of a fragment of Maecenas)
translation: Make me weak in the hands, weak in the feet and hips, dash out my failing teeth. So long as life remains 'tis well.
notes: The words of a man who clings to life at any cost.

quotation: Debito justitiae, or E debito justitiae.
translation: By debt of justice.
notes: By virtue of a claim justly established.

quotation: Deceptio visus.
translation: A deceiving of the sight.
notes: An illusion practised on the eye. "An ocular deception."

quotation: Decet affectus animi neque se nimium erigere nec subjicere serviliter.
translation: We ought neither to allow the affections of the mind to become too much elated, nor yet abjectly depressed.

quotation: Decet patriam nobis cariorem esse quam nosmetipsos.
translation: Our country ought to be dearer to us than ourselves.

quotation: Decies repetita placebit.
translation: Ten times repeated it will please.
notes: It will be encored again and again.

quotation: Decipimur specie recti.
translation: We are deceived by an appearance of rectitude.

quotation: Decipit Frons prima multos; rara mens intelligit Quod interiore condidit cura angulo.
translation: First appearances deceive many; the penetration of but few enables them to discern that which has been carefully concealed in the inmost corners of the heart.

quotation: Decorum ab honesto non potest separari.
translation: Propriety cannot be separated from what is honourable.

quotation: Dedecet philosophum abjicere animum.
translation: It is unbecoming in a philosopher to be dejected.

quotation: Dedecorant bene nata culpae.
translation: Vices disgrace what is naturally good.

quotation: Dedimus potestatem.
translation: We have given power.
notes: A writ, or commission, giving certain powers, for the purpose of speeding the business of the court.

quotation: Dediscit animus sero quod didicit diu.
translation: The mind is slow to unlearn what it has been long in learning.
notes: Impressions once made on the mind are not easily erased.

quotation: Dedit hanc contagio labem, Et dabit in plures.
translation: Contagion has caused this plague-spot, and will extend it to many more.

quotation: Defectio virium adolescentiae vitiis efficitur sapius quam senectutis.
translation:
Loss of strength is more frequently the 
fault of youth than of old age.

quotation: Defendit numerus junctaeque umbone phalanges.
translation: He is defended by their numbers, and the array of their serried shields.

quotation: Defluit saxis agitatus humor, Concidunt venti, fugiuntque nubes, Et minax, (nam sic voluere,) ponto Unda recumbit.
translation: The troubled surge falls down from the rocks, the winds cease, the clouds vanish, and the threatening waves, (for such is the will of the sons of Leda,) subside.

quotation: Deforme est de seipso praedicare, falso praesertim.
translation:
It is unseemly to talk of one's self, and more especially to 
state falsehoods.

quotation: Deformius nihil est ardelione sene.
translation: There is nothing more unseemly than an aged busybody.

quotation: Degeneres animos timor arguit.
translation: Fear shows an ignoble mind.

quotation: Dei plena sunt omnia.
translation: All things are full of God.
notes: See Sunt Jovis, &c.

quotation: Delectando pariterque monendo.
translation: Pleasing as well as instructing.
notes: Having an eye both to the useful and the ornamental. See Omne tulit, &c.

quotation: Delegata potestas non potest delegari.
translation: A power that is delegated cannot again be delegated.
notes: That is, by the person to whom it is delegated.

quotation: Delenda est Carthago.
translation: Carthage must be destroyed.
notes: A phrase with which Cato the Elder used to end all his speeches, to stimulate the people to the destruction of Carthage, which from its wealth and commerce he looked upon as the most dangerous enemy of Rome.

quotation: Deleo omnes dehinc ex animo mulieres.
translation: From henceforth I blot out all women from my mind.

quotation: Deliberando saepe perit occasio.
